rules.title: OS Credential Dumping Detection
rules.description: Detects OS Credential Dumping activity via process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate use of rundll32.exe for system administration tasks
False positives may occur if Comsvcs.dll is loaded for non-malicious purposes

rules.description: Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Account Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Account Discovery activity via command line using tools like net user, dsquery user, Get-LocalUser, and whoami

rules.title: Remote Desktop Protocol Detection
rules.description: Detects Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate RDP connections from IT administrators
Remote workers using RDP for legitimate purposes

rules.description: Detects User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Write-Host 'This is a phishing simulation'; Read-Host 'Enter your credentials'"
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing prompt using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts the user to enter credentials, simulating a phishing attempt.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a phishing email > %TEMP%\phish.txt && start %TEMP%\phish.txt
attacks.description: Create a temporary file that could mimic a phishing email and open it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the temp directory with a phishing message and opens it, simulating receipt of a phishing email.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName('System.Windows.Forms'); $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Simulation'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Enter your credentials'; $form.Controls.Add($label); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using Windows Forms to create a dialog box.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a form asking for credentials, simulating an advanced phishing attempt.

attacks.command: echo 'Phishing email content' > phishing_email.txt; cat phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Create and display a fake phishing email
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a file named phishing_email.txt and display its content

attacks.description: Download and display a fake phishing web page
attacks.expected_behavior: Download the content of https://example.com and save it to a file named phishing_page.html, then display the file content

attacks.description: Download and display a fake phishing web page using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Download the file https://example.com/phishing_page.html and save it to the current directory, then display the file content

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command execution to get the current date.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes and displays the current date without any issues.

attacks.description: Intermediate command involving downloading a string from a local file using WebClient.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to download the contents of a file named test.txt from the %TEMP% directory, simulating a potential malicious activity without causing harm.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { Remove-Item -Path '$env:TEMP\test.txt' -ErrorAction Stop } catch { Write-Warning 'Failed to remove file'; } finally { Get-ChildItem -Path $env:TEMP }"
attacks.description: Advanced command that includes error handling and silent continuation, attempting to remove a file and then listing the %TEMP% directory contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to remove a file named test.txt from the %TEMP% directory. If the removal fails, it writes a warning. Regardless of the outcome, it lists the contents of the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to get running processes using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux, demonstrating file operation with -Force.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named 'testfile.txt' in '/tmp' with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage using PowerShell on Linux, assuming internet access for demonstration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the webpage from 'http://example.com' and saves it as '/tmp/example.html'.

attacks.description: Create a new system service using the sc.exe command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system service named MyService will be created

attacks.description: Start the Task Manager process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The Task Manager will be started

attacks.description: Modify the system's Run registry key to start a new process
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will start the specified process on the next boot

attacks.description: Start the nginx service using systemctl, demonstrating creation or modification of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The nginx service will be started, creating or modifying a system process

attacks.description: Open the crontab editor to schedule a new task, demonstrating modification of system processes
attacks.expected_behavior: The user will be able to schedule a new task, potentially modifying system processes

attacks.description: Update the init script for nginx using update-rc.d, demonstrating creation or modification of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The init script for nginx will be updated, creating or modifying a system process

attacks.description: Basic process injection using PowerShell to start notepad.exe and inject calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe will start and calc.exe will be injected into it

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using certutil to encode a command and inject it into cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Cmd.exe will start and calc.exe will be injected into it

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to start powershell.exe and inject an encoded command
attacks.expected_behavior: Powershell.exe will start and the encoded command will be injected into it

attacks.description: Basic process injection using gdb to allocate and fill memory in a running process
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to attach to a running process with PID 1234, allocate memory, fill it with NOP instructions, and then detach from the process.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using ptrace to attach to and detach from a running process
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to attach to a running process with PID 1234 and then detach from it, demonstrating process injection capabilities.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using gdb to load a malicious library and execute a function from it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to attach to a running process with PID 1234, load a malicious library, execute a function from it, and then detach from the process.

attacks.description: Starting the Telnet service to simulate a basic C2 channel establishment.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Telnet service starts, allowing for potential C2 communication.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to execute a simple command, simulating an intermediate level of C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes, printing 'Hello, World!' to the console, demonstrating the ability to execute commands via PowerShell.

attacks.description: Utilizing certutil to download a benign file, simulating an advanced C2 communication scenario where data is fetched from a remote location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign.txt file is downloaded to the %TEMP% directory, demonstrating the capability to fetch data from a remote URL.

attacks.description: Simulate a GET request over HTTP to demonstrate application layer protocol usage for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a GET request to the specified URL, demonstrating the use of the HTTP protocol for potential command and control activities.

attacks.description: Use DNS protocol to resolve a domain name, showing another application layer protocol in use.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command resolves the domain name using DNS, illustrating the application layer protocol's role in command and control communications.

attacks.description: Download content from a URL without saving it, demonstrating covert communication over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the content from the specified URL but discards it, simulating a covert communication channel over the HTTP protocol.

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encoded file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated script using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an obfuscated script in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a hidden share using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a hidden share on the C drive

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' > file.txt; base64 file.txt > encoded_file.txt
attacks.description: Encode a file using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'file.txt' with the content 'Hello World', then encode it using base64 and save it to 'encoded_file.txt'

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' > file.txt; gzip file.txt; base64 file.txt.gz > encoded_file.txt
attacks.description: Compress and encode a file using gzip and base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'file.txt' with the content 'Hello World', then compress it using gzip, encode it using base64, and save it to 'encoded_file.txt'

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' > file.txt; openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -in file.txt -out encrypted_file.txt
attacks.description: Encrypt a file using openssl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'file.txt' with the content 'Hello World', then encrypt it using openssl and save it to 'encrypted_file.txt'

attacks.description: This command simulates the exfiltration of sensitive data by first compressing a file into a zip archive and then sending this archive over a hypothetical C2 channel via HTTP POST.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compresses a file, then attempts to send it over HTTP, simulating data exfiltration without actually exfiltrating real data.

attacks.description: This command uses certutil to simulate the exfiltration of a file over a C2 channel by caching a URL that supposedly contains exfiltrated data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to cache a URL, simulating the retrieval of exfiltrated data without actually transferring real sensitive information.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\exfiltration_log.txt' -Value 'Exfiltration attempt logged.' -Force; Start-Process -FilePath 'cmd' -ArgumentList '/c, echo Exfiltration attempt > %TEMP%\exfiltration_log.txt'"
attacks.description: This command demonstrates an advanced scenario by logging an exfiltration attempt both through PowerShell and the legacy cmd.exe, showcasing versatility in command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command logs an exfiltration attempt using both PowerShell and cmd.exe, demonstrating command execution versatility without causing actual harm.

attacks.description: Exfiltrate /etc/passwd file over a netcat connection to example.com on port 8080
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to establish a connection to example.com on port 8080 and sends the contents of /etc/passwd over this connection.

attacks.description: Exfiltrate /etc/hosts file using curl to POST its contents to example.com
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the contents of /etc/hosts as a POST request to the specified URL.

attacks.description: Exfiltrate /etc/shadow file in base64 format over a netcat connection to example.com on port 8081
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes /etc/shadow in base64 and sends it over a netcat connection, which could potentially expose sensitive information.

attacks.description: Downloads a potentially malicious payload using certutil and executes it. This simulates exploiting a public-facing application by leveraging a built-in tool for downloading and executing files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to download a file from a specified URL and execute it. In a real attack scenario, this could lead to code execution. For testing purposes, ensure 'example.com/malicious_payload.exe' is replaced with a benign payload or a non-existent URL to avoid actual harm.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to download a potentially exploitable script from a public-facing application and executes it. This demonstrates how an attacker might exploit a vulnerability in a web application to execute malicious scripts.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from a specified URL and executes it using Invoke-Expression. For safety, replace 'http://example.com/exploit' with a benign script or ensure the URL does not point to actual malicious content.

attacks.description: Uses the net start command to start network services and then lists all listening ports using netstat. This can help in identifying potential public-facing applications that could be exploited.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command starts network services and lists all ports that are in a listening state, which can be useful for identifying services that could potentially be exploited.

attacks.description: Basic exploitation attempt using curl to send a GET request with an exploit parameter to a hypothetical vulnerable web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to exploit a public-facing web application by sending a crafted GET request. The expected behavior is that the web server processes the request, potentially triggering the exploit if the application is vulnerable.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation attempt using wget to send a POST request with exploit data to a vulnerable web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses wget to send a POST request with exploit data to the vulnerable application. The expected behavior is similar to the previous command but uses a different tool and request method.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation attempt using bash to create a temporary file with exploit data and then using curl to send a POST request with the file content to the vulnerable web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command demonstrates a more complex scenario where a temporary file is created with exploit data, and then curl is used to send the contents of this file as a POST request to the vulnerable application. The expected behavior involves the successful execution of the bash script and the processing of the exploit data by the web application.

attacks.description: Basic command to list user accounts, potentially useful for identifying targets for credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: Intermediate command attempting to backup the SAM hive, which contains user credentials, to a file. Requires administrative privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves the SAM registry hive to a file, potentially allowing for offline credential extraction.

attacks.description: Advanced command using PowerShell to search for credential files in user directories, handling errors silently to avoid detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the Credentials directory for all users, potentially identifying stored credentials.

attacks.description: Dumping the passwd file to potentially extract user credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of the passwd file, which may include user credentials.

attacks.description: Using getent to display user credentials from the passwd database
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user credentials from the system's passwd database.

attacks.description: Searching for password occurrences in /etc/ directory and subdirectories
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds and displays lines containing the word 'password' from files in /etc/ and its subdirectories, potentially revealing credential storage locations.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving a collected data file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of a test file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "cd %TEMP% && echo Test Data > collected_data.txt && zip -m archived.zip collected_data.txt"
attacks.description: Intermediate example using legacy binaries to create and archive a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file with test data in the temp directory and archives it using the zip command.

attacks.description: Advanced example using PowerShell to create a zip archive from a directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive named advanced_archive.zip in the temp directory containing all files from a 'Collect' directory.

attacks.description: This command collects data from a specified path and archives it using tar with gzip compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tarball named collected_data.tar.gz in the current directory containing the data from /path/to/data.

attacks.description: This command collects data from a specified path and archives it using zip.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip file named collected_data.zip in the current directory containing the data from /path/to/data.

attacks.description: This command collects data from a specified path and archives it using 7z.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a 7z archive named collected_data.7z in the current directory containing the data from /path/to/data.

attacks.description: Create a daily task named 'Test Task' that writes 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task 'Test Task' is created and runs daily, writing to a file without causing any harm.

attacks.description: Query the details of the 'Test Task' task using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Details of the 'Test Task' are displayed, showing its current state and settings.

attacks.description: Delete the 'Test Task' task. The `/f` option forces the deletion without prompting for confirmation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'Test Task' task is deleted. Note that using `/f` can be risky if not used carefully, as it does not prompt for confirmation.

attacks.description: Opens the cron table for editing, allowing for the addition of new scheduled tasks.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor set for the user will open, displaying the current cron table. The user can then add, modify, or delete scheduled tasks.

attacks.description: Adds a new scheduled task to run a command at midnight every day without requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command appends a new cron job to the user's existing cron table, scheduling the specified command to run daily at midnight.

attacks.description: Opens the cron table for a specific user for editing, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command allows an admin to edit the cron table of a specified user, enabling the addition of scheduled tasks that run under that user's context.

attacks.description: Enumerate local user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists local user accounts

attacks.description: Enumerate local groups
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists local groups

attacks.description: Enumerate local user accounts using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists local user accounts

attacks.description: Enumerate all user accounts on the system by retrieving entries from the password database.
attacks.expected_behavior: Display a list of all user accounts on the system, including their user ID, group ID, GECOS field, home directory, and shell.

attacks.description: Display information about the current user, including their user ID, group ID, and the groups they belong to.
attacks.expected_behavior: Show the user ID, group ID, and group memberships of the current user.

attacks.description: List the groups a specific user is a member of.
attacks.expected_behavior: Display the groups that the specified user belongs to.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection to localhost for testing RDP protocol detection
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a local RDP connection to test detection capabilities without causing harm

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to start an RDP connection to localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses PowerShell to start an RDP connection, testing detection of RDP protocol activity initiated through PowerShell

attacks.description: Advanced command using cmd.exe to start an RDP connection and then exit, simulating a command chain
attacks.expected_behavior: Tests the detection of RDP activity within a command chain, ensuring the system can identify the protocol use even in more complex scenarios

attacks.description: Simulate starting an xrdp session to mimic RDP activity
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to start an xrdp session, which could trigger detection rules looking for RDP-like activity.

attacks.description: Listen on port 3389 to simulate RDP server activity
attacks.expected_behavior: This command listens on the default RDP port, which could be detected as potential RDP activity.

attacks.description: Simulate an RDP connection to localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to connect to an RDP server on localhost, which is a safe and controlled test of RDP client activity.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious executable from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be downloaded and executed, potentially causing harm to the system

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious PowerShell script from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious PowerShell script will be downloaded and executed, potentially causing harm to the system

attacks.description: Creates a malicious batch file and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious batch file will be created and executed, potentially causing harm to the system

attacks.description: Execute a malicious script using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed, potentially leading to unauthorized access or data compromise.

attacks.description: Make a malicious file executable and then execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be made executable and then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized access or data compromise.

attacks.description: Execute a malicious script using bash with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed with elevated privileges, potentially leading to significant unauthorized access or data compromise.
